newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila call loan rates up on weekend covering.
newsitem.headline: Manila call loan rates up on weekend covering.

text.p: * Volume expands to 26.374 bln from 17.056 bln pesos
Philippine interbank call loan rates rose sligthly on Monday to an average of 10.9375 from 10.8125 percent amid the covering of reserve positions for the weekend, traders said.
Done rates ranged from 11.375 to 10.78125 percent, with 31 lenders and 29 borrowers.
"The market would be sideways for the rest of the week, a dealer said.
"Outflows and inflows are just about even," she added.
Though some 2.4 billion pesos of maturities had been expected early this week, it will be offset by some 2.0 billion pesos in payment for T-notes later in the week, she said.
In the secondary market for T-bills, trading was tepid as institutions awaited results of the primary T-bill auction later in the day, traders said.
"They (banks) think the rates at the secondary market are too low. They might have a chance of getting better rates at the auction," a dealer said.
According to a Reuters survey of eight institutions, the three-month bills had offer rates of 11.25 to 11.475; the six months at 11.65 to 11.825; and the one year at 12.075 to 12.225.
